title: 112_hr2535
content: The Act may be cited as the "College Literacy in Finance and Economics Act of 2011" or the "College LIFE Act." Congress finds that student borrowing is prevalent in higher education, with over $100 billion in Federal education loans originated annually. In 2008, 62% of baccalaureate degree recipients graduated with student debt. Additionally, a significant percentage of students at public, private, and for-profit institutions borrow money for college expenses. In the same year, a high percentage of minority students received financial aid. In 2008, the average student loan debt among graduates was $23,186, with 1 in 10 having at least $40,000 in debt. 57% of for-profit institution graduates owed over $30,000. Student debt has been increasing by 5.6% annually since 2003. For-profit institution students make up 47% of all loan defaults despite being only 10% of all students. Since 2003, the national cohort default rate has increased from 4.5 percent to 7 percent. 56% of dependent students at higher education institutions had a credit card in their name in 2004, with an average balance of $2,000. 56% of adults in the US do not have a budget or track expenses. According to research, consumers who received financial education had fewer delinquent accounts and remained current on their accounts longer. Less than 1/3 of young adults set aside emergency savings. 62% of high school students struggle with basic personal finance, and financial literacy scores among future higher education students are low. According to research, schools like the University of Arizona are trusted by students to increase their knowledge of personal finance. SEC. 3. FINANCIAL LITERACY COUNSELING. Section 485 of the Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to include a requirement for eligible institutions to provide financial literacy counseling to borrowers through various means such as financial aid offices, designated employees, or partnerships with nonprofit organizations experienced in financial education. The Economic Education Act of 2001 requires financial literacy counseling for borrowers at two key points: entrance counseling within 45 days of the first loan disbursement and exit counseling before the end of the loan term. The Economic Education Act of 2001 mandates financial literacy counseling for borrowers at specific times, including before completing their course of study or upon leaving the institution. Exceptions apply to certain types of loans. The Economic Education Act of 2001 requires financial literacy counseling for borrowers, including a minimum of 4 hours before completing their studies and an additional 4 hours upon leaving the institution. Up to 2 hours of counseling for each occasion can be provided electronically. The Economic Education Act of 2001 mandates financial literacy counseling for borrowers, including information on student financial aid such as loans, grants, tax credits, and scholarships. If a borrower leaves an eligible institution without prior notice, the institution must attempt to provide the required information in writing. The Economic Education Act of 2001 mandates financial literacy counseling for borrowers, including information on student financial aid such as loans, grants, tax credits, and scholarships. It covers educational loans, differences between loan types, banking basics, budgeting, and saving. The curr_chunk discusses budgeting, saving, credit, and debt management, including responsible credit card use and common credit products like debit cards and student loan debit cards. It emphasizes the importance of setting financial goals and developing savings plans. The curr_chunk covers credit agreements, responsible card use, repayment, consequences of minimum payments, investing in common products, setting investment goals, risks and benefits, assessing risk tolerance, and understanding credit scores. The curr_chunk provides information on credit scores, factors affecting credit scores, building a strong credit history, housing topics like renting and mortgage borrowing, and tax filing and planning. The curr_chunk discusses tax consequences of financial decisions, responsible financial decision making, and the use of interactive programs to test borrower's understanding of financial literacy information. The Secretary will develop a curriculum for eligible institutions to fulfill the requirements of the College Literacy in Finance and Economics Act of 2011, consulting with the Financial Literacy and Education Commission.
